oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fulton Street, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of homes on Fulton Street. Fulton Street later became Merrick Road. Postmark: "Freeport, New York, June 25, 1906, 12 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Mr. Halstead Smith, Richfield Springs, N.Y." Message: "June 25, 1906, Rec'd your postal. Glad you got through your trip so well. Take good care of yourself. Will write again. C.G.A. Ms. Healy's address is South Collon, N.Y."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Fulton Street - Freeport (N.Y.); Houses; Dwellings; Streets; Merrick Road - Freeport (N.Y.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight small black and white photographs of: Crystal Lake Inn, Freeport Bank, Freeport Club House, Woodcleft Canal, Oyster Boats, Yachting on Great So. Postmark: "Freeport, New York, August 1909, 5 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss M B Wheeler, Baldwin, N.Y." Message: "Here's a new one - out today. S.F.P."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Church of the Transfiguration Church, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color postcard of the Church of the Transfiguration located on the east side of South Long Beach Avenue, south of Pine Street. This Episcopal church, was built in 1894 and later replaced by a brick church in 1951. Postmark: "August 18, 1926, Freeport, N.Y., 5:30 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Mrs. F.C. Donovan, Long Beach, Mississippi" Message: "Here for a flying trip. Having a fine time. George and (illegible) in good spirits. Wish you were here. Love, Lill"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of Main Street and Sunrise Highway. Olive Building appears on the left hand side of photograph with a running on Main Street. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grove Theatre, Freeport, L.I., N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color postcard of the Grove Theatre, located on Merrick Road. Dolores Costello is listed on the marquee. The store next to the theater is an ice cream/chocolate store owned by Karaman and Mercer. Postmark: "Brooklyn, N.Y. May 25, 1935, 7 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss Dotey Weston, 12 Shonard Ave., Freeport, L.I." Message: "Hello Dot, Arrived home [illegible]. Went to work this morning. Don't know if we will make the trip to Rochester this week or not. Will see you Thursday afternoon an [sic] let you know. Give my Best Regards to all. Love Ansel. "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Spanish War Trophy, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of the cannon located on Main Street and Church Street. "Trubia", made in Spain in 1874 was captured by American during the Spanish American War in 1898. This war trophy was unveiled in 1902. Charles P. Smith building can be seen behind the cannon. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y. July 6, 1906, 8 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Haktead Smith, Richfield Springs, N.Y." Message: "Club House Fire Work Saturday Night."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Church Street - Freeport (N.Y.); Main Street--Freeport (N.Y.); Cannons;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard. The top photograph is of the Woodcleft Inn, which later became the Catholic Fresh Air Home. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First National Bank, Railroad Avenue, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the First National Bank and the Freeport Railroad Station, looking east down Railroad Avenue. Postmark: "Freeport, October 13, 1916. " Addressee and Address: "Mrs. Ethie Turner, Branch Street, Bennington, VT" Message: "Dear Mother, First a line to let you know that we are well and having a good time. Hope you are the same. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of Randall's Park, Freeport, L.I., N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of John J. Randall's estate. Known as "Woodbine", Mr. Randall's palatial home was located off of Lena Avenue. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., August 17, 1925, 7:30 a.m." Addressee and Address: "Mr. W. W. Raynor, 261 Union Ave., Saratoga Springs, N.Y." Message: "Dear Daddy Raynor, We are going to take a trip beginning Aug. 30th. Bols' vacation starts then. We thought of taking a trip up there, but Ma won't come so I don't know just what we will do. Marion [asks] did you get any money on guessing. She hopes your field glasses are not broken. With Love, Marion."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Randall, John Jay, (1846-1924); Woodbine--Freeport (N.Y.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport Bathing Beach, Freeport, L.I., N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of Freeport Bathing Beach. Same postcard as item - 1962.002.047 but colorized differently.Â¹ostmark: "Middleburg, N.Y. June 13, 19--, 7 a.m." Addressee and Address: Marie Von Thecelen, c/o Mr. Allard, "25 Edgewood Lane, Bronxville" Message in German: "June 12, 1939 [or 1934] Liebe Schwester! Habe gestern Deine Zeitungen bei bestem Whohlsein erhalten. Hatte hier kaltes wetter. Viele gaerten sind verfroren. Corn, gurken and tomatoes und gestern eine fuerchterliche hitze. Heute abend regnet es schoen lngsam. Es gruesst Nick" English translation: "Dear sister! Received your newspapers yesterday in best condition. Had cold weather here. Many gardens froze. Corn, cucumber and tomatos and yesterday an awful heat. This evening it is raining nice and slow. Greetings, Nick"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport Theatre, Freeport, L.I., N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the Freeport Theatre located on Sunrise Highway at Henry Street. Century Theaters ran this theater as well as the Grove Theatre on Merrick Road. In 1922, the Freeport Theater Corporation, headed by Col. Robert Rasmussen, arranged to spend nearly one-third of a million dollars for the Freeport Theatre. This theater closed in 1972. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., August 21, 1924" Addressee and Address: "Joseph McShea, 151 Fifth Ave., Long Island City, Astoria" Message: "Wednesday. Dear Joe, Millie and the bunch was over last night and Elsie left her pocket book at the house and I will keep it for them. Please let them know at once so they won't be worried about it. Clara"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport L.I. Woodclift Home [Woodcleft Inn]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of the Woodcleft Inn that is identified in the postcard as the "Woodclift Home." Woodcleft Inn faced Front Street at the head of Woodcleft Canal and house 200 guests. The inn eventually became a Catholic orphanage and/or summer camp maintained by the St. Vincent DePaul Society. In the early 1940s, the Village of Freeport purchased the structure to enlarge Randall Park. Postmark: Addressee and Address: "Mr. Jack Lewis, 217 Monroe St., Brooklyn" Message: "Having a great time. Sorry you didn't get down. M."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of three boys on a bridge at the Fishing Pool. This early bridge on Mill Road covered the millrace from Horsfal's Pond to a grist and saw mill. Suppose they are near there now. Just had a letter from Aunt Sue. Have you any idea where you will be home[?] Was in city last week Sat. Bought you a bag. With love, M."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Church of Our Holy Redeemer, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of Our Holy Redeemer Church. The Reverend Thomas E. Carroll of Rockville Centre celebrated, on Christmas Day, 1895, the first mass for Roman Catholics in Freeport at the home of William Dougherty on Merrick Road. Two years later, when parishioners had increased to 75, the Reverend Patrick Fitzgerald had charge of the mission. Starting in 1899, the Reverend William Farrell, pastor at Hempstead, celebrated mass at Willis Hall on Main Street. The original church, located where the parochial school now stands on Pine Street, was completed in 1900 and parishioners bought property surrounding it for transfer to the church. During the pastorate of Reverend Charles A. Logue (1902-13) a site for the new church was acquired and the first portion of the present edifice at Ocean Avenue and Pine Street opened on Easter 1911. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 12].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main St., at Randall Ave., showing the Oldest House in Freeport, L.I. - Built in 1806
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the oldest house in Freeport. Built in 1795, the Bedell Homestead was Freeport's oldest home. Originally located in the undeveloped Bedell Woods (between Ocean and Randall Avenues), this house was moved 50 years later to the northwest corner of Randall Avenue and North Main Street. This house survived until the 1950s when it was demolished to make room for an apartment house. Rowland H. Mayland, manufacturer of musical instruments, was among the dwelling's prominent owners. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 7].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Oldest House in Freeport]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the oldest house in Freeport. Built in 1795, the Bedell Homestead was Freeport's oldest home. Originally located in the undeveloped Bedell Woods (between Ocean and Randall Avenues), this house was moved 50 years later to the northwest corner of Randall Avenue and North Main Street. This house survived until the 1950s when it was demolished to make room for an apartment house. Roland H. Mayland, manufacturer of musical instruments, was among the dwelling's prominent owners. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 7].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Presbyterian Church and Sunday School, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of the Presbyterian Church. The Presbyterians first used Freeport's original schoolhouse located on Main and Church Streets for Sunday services. In 1840, a group of residents decided to start a mission of Hempstead's Presbyterian Church, using a building on Main Street's east side at about where Sunrise Highway now runs through. When this proved inadequate, they replaced it with a third church located on the northwest corner of Main Street and Merrick Road. When in 1859 Methodists opened a church only 100 feet or so north, each of the two groups disturbed the other with the sound of its hymns and organ. In 1860, the Presbyterians moved to a church on Raynor Street (now Church Street) remaining there until 1964 when a larger site on South Ocean Avenue was acquired. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 12].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Steele Ship Peter Rickmers, ashore at Short Beach, after the storm
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the shipwrecked Peter Rickmers. The four masted German square-rigger Peter Rickmers, became stranded in thick weather at 7:10 p.m., on April 30, 1908, a mile and half from the U.S. Life Saving Station at Short Beach. Her cargo, 125 thousand cases of kerosene and crude oil, was loaded at Perth Amboy and was destined for Rangoon, Burma. On the evening of May 8, the 33 members of crew were rescued. The Peter Rickmers later broke up and became a total loss littering the beach for miles with tins of oil. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., May 23, - a.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss Alice Schneider, Freeport, L.I." Message: "Dear Alice, There is a game with Hempstead tomorrow. If you will come up, I will be able to see you. As ever yours, A.N.H."
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Shipwrecks; Peter Rickmers (Ship);
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stafford

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Catholic Fresh Air Home, Freeport, L.I., N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the Catholic Fresh Air Home. Formerly the Woodcleft Inn, this building faced Front Street at the head of Woodcleft Canal . The inn eventually became a Catholic orphanage and/or summer camp maintained by the St. Vincent DePaul Society. In the early 1940's, the Village of Freeport purchased the structure to enlarge Randall Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport War Camp Community Service Club House, Decorated for Welcome Home Day
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Freeport's War Camp Community Service Clubhouse, located at Church Street and Olive Boulevard [Sunrise Highway]. Formerly, Schwab's Tavern, this hospitality center brought cheer and relaxation to an average about 1,500 World War I servicemen each week. The War Camp Community Center offered refreshments in its front room, while in the west portion a dance floor accommodated orchestras along with entertainment. There was also space to chat, read or write. The center was formerly housed in one or two small buildings on Brooklyn Avenue until it outgrew those quarters. Leaders of the War Camp Community Service clubhouse included, Sidney Swezey, president of the canteen, Smith F. Pearsall, publisher of the Nassau County Review, and F. Howard Covey. James Sutphin headed the committee that ran two weekly dances and Mrs. John Hartmann had charge of meals. Records show that entertainment consisting of games, sing-alongs and special performers, was presented on 141 nights and 10,000 cakes were consumed. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 29].
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Clubhouses; World War, 1914-1918.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Freeport Historical Museum]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sketch of the Freeport Historical Museum building. One year after the Freeport Historical Society was founded in April 1961, a historical museum at 350 South Main Street was established. Charter members and other contributors, helped to finance the purchase of the museum building through a $5,000 mortgage, covering almost the entire cost. Granted a permanent charter by New York State, the museum is entitled to tax-free status as an educational institution. Anyone who owns an item of historical value or has knowledge about people, places, or events from Freeport's past, are encouraged to contact the Freeport Historical Museum. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 24].

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Where the Lilies Grow - Freeport, L.I.,
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the northerly end of Smart's Paper Mill pond. This picture was identified in A Pictorial History of Early Freeport, New York, collected and annotated by former village historian, John F. DeLorme, 1955 (page 43) This mill was established in 1835, and with four other paper mills, was situated slightly north of the present village boundary line, now Roosevelt, but was years before Freeport had definite boundaries. It is said that paper from the mill was used in Webster's Speller and Thompson's History of Long Island. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., August 23, 1910, 12 p.m.' Addressee and Address: "Miss Beatrice Vail, Ledgewood Farm House, Round Top, Greene Co. N.Y." Message: "August 23, '10, Arrived home at 8:20. The boat was late. Everything is o.k. Will write later, Edna"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Railroad Station, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the Freeport Railroad Station located on Sunrise highway. This picture shows the railroad tracks before they were elevated. Also visable is the H.P Libby Real Estate building, the Methodist Church steeple, and stores located along Railroad Avenue. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., August 2, 5 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss Beatrice Vail, Ledgewood Farm, Round Top, Greene Co. New York" Message: "Dear Beatrice, Just rec'd your card. Am glad to hear you are having a good time. It is rather quiet in Freeport now. Expect to away part of August. Doesn't the picture on this card look sort of familiar[?] Hope to hear from you again soon with lots love, Astrid"

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of Freeport's Municipal Building, commonly referred to as Village Hall. Printed message on back: "Freeport, Long Island. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport, N.Y., Episcopal Church
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color postcard of the Church of the Transfiguration located on the east side of South Long Beach Avenue, south of Pine Street. This Episcopal church, was built in 1894 and later replaced by a brick church in 1951. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., December 2, 1907, 12 a.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss L. Adele Miller, Greenport, Long Island, N.Y." Message: "Dec. 2nd, 1907. Dear Adele, I was in this church last night for the fist time. We have snow this morning. It [is] well you didn't come home. The two [illegible] home also, others for Thanksgiving Holiday. With love, Mother. You have a turkey from F.H. M. Postal"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wood Cleft Bay Fresh Air Home, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of Woodcleft Canal and the Catholic Fresh Air Home. Formerly the Woodcleft Inn, this building faced Front Street at the head of Woodcleft Canal . The inn eventually became a Catholic orphanage and/or summer camp maintained by the St. Vincent DePaul Society. In the early 1940's, the Village of Freeport purchased the structure to enlarge Randall Park. Addressee and Address: " Mrs. Wm. [Illegible], Bennington, Vermont"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Osterhout Home]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of a house. [Note on postcard indicates that the house depicted was Osterhout home, located on the northwest corner of Merrick Road and Long Beach Avenue]. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., March 31, 1923, 6 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Mrs. S. R. Smith, c/o Heighlawn Pines Inn, Southern Pines, North Carolina" Message: "We [illegible] home on time Friday morning. In Penn Station at 6 o'clock sharp. Found everything in "ship shape" - and every one apparently glade to see us. Of course, I went to see the baby first and found her happy and growing. [Illegible] night hours I think. Nellie met her at station. I called up Edna in p.m. She is getting on, but slowly. Doris not dare venture out any more until weather gets warm as she has suffered each time she has gone. Mr. O. and I attended service in Episcopal Church Fri. p.m. union service. Many [illegible] conference begins April 11 - at Bridgeport. I understand March is leaving lion like - clear but cold with N.W. wind blowing. I am shivering this morning tho [sic] the house is warm. Love, Jessie"

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of William Livery Stable. This photograph was probably taken about 1900. This stable was located on the west side of South Main Street. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport, L.I., Crystal Lake, Inn
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the Crystal Lake Inn located on the northwest corner of South Grove Street (Guy Lombardo Avenue) and Southside Avenue. Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y. Sept. 9, 1910, 5 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Mrs. A.E. Frost, 137 Remson St., Brooklyn, N.Y." Message: "Dear Mrs. F. My dogs and your bird is [sic] welll. Taken care of and don't you think the house looks well. Everybody is happy and I hope you are. Love to all, Hannah"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crystal Lake House, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Colorized postcard of the Crystal Lake Hotel. Postmark: "Sailors Mail" Addressee and Address: "Mrs. Allie E. Frost, Cystal Lake House, Freeport, L.I., N.Y. U.S.A." Message: "2-14-19 Dearest, The Crystal Lake Haouse in France a wild time the short while I was in town. Have a [illegible] for you and don't expect to lose it this time. Lovingly, Ward" This postcard was probably sent from Edward P. Ward, the former proprietor of the Crystal Lake Hotel, to his wife, Allie E. Frost.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport Fire Department
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of five Freeport Fire Houses. Early firehouses include: (upper left) Excelsior Hook and Ladder Co. No. 1, Church Street just south of the present firehouse; (lower left) Vigilant Hose Co. No. 2, North Main Street; (lower center) Wide Awake Engine Co. No. 2 in Silas Williams livery stable, 54 South Main Street; (upper center) Bayview Hose Co. No. 3, Bayview Avenue south of Atlantic Avenue; (upper right) Ever Ready Hose Co. No. 1 east side of Bedell Street below Smith Street, later moved to 41 Mill Road and torn down. [Description from: Freeport as It Was, Clinton Metz, 1976, page 25] Postmark: "July 23, 1908, 12 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss L. Adele Miller, Greenport, Long Island, N.Y." Message: "7/23/08 Dear Adele, Haven't heard from you yet suppose you are busy. Sevino went same night at 8 got there at 11. We were at the carnival last night- had dinner. The mosquitoes nearly at us up. With love, Mother." [On front] "The parade was very good. Had several visiting companies. It rained quite hard some of the time."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of South Main Street looking south from the cannon. The photograph was probably taken around 1905. The stone-faced building on the left was the Freeport Bank. The tall building on the right was Van Riper's Hall, widely used for public meetings. It was in that building that the first meeting was held to discuss the incorporation of Freeport. This picture was identified in A Pictorial History of Early Freeport, New York, collected and annotated by former Village Historian, John F. DeLorme, 1955 (page 59). Address and Addressee: " Miss Alice Schneider, Freeport, L.I." Message: "Dear Alice, Please forgive me for yesterday's disappointment, but will explain Tuesday night. It was no fault of mine. Jack" [On front] "This is as near as I can get at present, but wait until Tuesday night. Jack"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Main Street--Freeport (N.Y.); Freeport Bank--Freeport (N.Y.); Van Riper's Hall--Freeport (N.Y.); Streets

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Main Street, Freeport, L.I.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white postcard of the northeast corner of Merrick Road and Main Street taken in 1904. Stores line the street including Seaman's Dry Goods store. Barbershop pole is visible on the left side of the photograph. tracks run down the street and a car can be seen in the distance. This picture was identified in A Pictorial History of Early Freeport, New York, collected and annotated by former Village Historian, John F. DeLorme, 1955 (page 67). Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., August 20, 1908, 5 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss Anna Wolfenberger, Grant Ave. near University Place, Woodhaven, Long Island." Message: "Dear Anna, I am so glad that you are coming at last. Sunday is all right. I am anxious to know all about your work. Do you like it? We intended to call but it was just noontime when we got to city line and we did not want to disrupt you meal. R. E. D."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Freeport, L.I., Freeport Bank
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postmark: "Freeport, N.Y., October 23, 1908, 12 p.m." Addressee and Address: "Miss Maude Nichols, Sidney, N.Y., Box 327" Message: "I don't know what you think of me for not thanking you for the fine maple syrup you sent and the trouble you took to get it. Enjoy it very much. Will try to write soon. There [illegible] been so much smoke. My eyes have troubled me a lot. [Illegible]."
